executive_summary:
Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency.

Postal service in the United States includes establishments that are part of the national postal service. The USPS, a major player in this industry, has been implementing reforms lately in response to dwindling performances, like cutting costs and pushing for higher prices. However, the effects of these reforms have been largely unsuccessful as they have still lost profit in this period. The agency, independent but under the guidance of the Postal Regulatory Commission, has also been preventing it from making more reforms, shaping how it performs in the period.

As online ways of distributing information have grown in popularity, traditional mail has become less popular, hurting this industry's performance. Private mail carriers have been a significant factor negatively impacting this industry because of their ability to offer identical types of services through savvier means and prices. Factors like the popularization of online media have also been hurting the USPS, as more people are using the internet, impacting how much physical mailing people need. Because of these factors, revenue for the postal service has been falling at a CAGR of 1.4% over the past five years and is expected to reach $79.7 billion in 2024. Revenue will drop 1.6% in that year.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Rise of Online Communication Has Been a Massive Threat to the USPS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: - Households and businesses have increasingly used the internet for socializing and conducting transactions. - The popularity of the internet has caused a drop in print advertising expenditures. Revenue from postage and advertising services has reduced over the decades as customers opt to use the internet for these services. - Online media has also reduced spending on periodicals, as many consumers now read newspapers and magazines on their computers or mobile devices.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Costly Operations Hurts This Industry's Profitability
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: - Various operating challenges have caused the USPS to struggle to balance its costs effectively during the period, which has cut its profit. - The agency has been reforming its operations by making cuts and pushing up prices. This has slightly slimmed its losses.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE ROBUST PRESENCE OF RIVAL INDUSTRIES HAS BEEN WORKING AGAINST THIS INDUSTRY
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: However, the agency is still losing profit. High costs and the agency's struggle to improve mailing volume have left it operating at a loss. Consumers still need a service to deliver their mail and packages. Despite the massive shifts in the market, the USPS remained afloat. However, with rival industries offering delivery services at competitive rates, it has been a struggle for the USPS to compete with the size and scope of companies like UPS and FedEx, making the postal service a less competitive industry. Because of these factors, the industry has lost revenue. Their rivals' ability to offer identical services cuts into their main revenue streams, creating more friction in their performance.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: REGULATORY BURDENS HAS BEEN SHAPING THE INDUSTRY'S PERFORMANCE
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The USPS's position as an independent agency that benefits from government support both aids and harms the industry. This support comes in the form of legislation that shapes its operations, like the Inflation Reduction Act, which grants funding to help the Postal Service enhance its vehicles, or the Postal Service Reform Act, which helps streamline its operations while cutting its financial obligations.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: External Competition is Expected to Soar
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As consumers become more used to using the Internet to conduct transactions and communicate messages, the need for traditional mail will continue to plunge. The postal service will also face threats from private companies that will improve and innovate their shipping and packaging services, preventing the USPS from gaining more ground during the period. Having more competition in these areas will shrink potential markets for this industry, causing a long-term slump for the USPS.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The USPS Will Downsize to Save Itself
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As revenue for the postal service will drop amid high competition, the USPS will have to downsize its operations to stay more financially sound. As demonstrated by the falling number of establishments, employment and wages, the postal service will eventually cut workers and close some post offices, a practice already starting now.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Efforts to save the USPS by Congress might give this industry a lifeline
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Even with a less united Congress, the need for the USPS for areas in rural parts of the United States will give it more credibility among lawmakers to provide support in emergencies.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE COST OF LIVING WILL BE IMPACTFUL ON FUTURE REVENUE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The cost of living will impact the future performance of the postal service as expensive home prices will hurt this industry's main demographic: residential consumers. Dropping homeowner rates may cut into the amount of household mail delivered by the postal service.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE POSTAL SERVICE HOPES NEW INNOVATIONS WILL BOOST ITS ATTRACTIVENESS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The USPS will offer more mobile apps to enable households and businesses to track mail efficiently while helping consumers keep in contact with them. The postal service will also make same-day delivery more common, adding more services to its operations and making shipping and packaging more efficient in the long run. The industry hopes these innovations will make their services as efficient as their rivals. The USPS will hope to reduce the long-term drop in revenue they're expected to display.

industry_definition: This industry includes establishments that are part of the national postal service and perform one or more postal services such as sorting, routing and delivery. Establishments that operate on a contract basis, except for the bulk transportation of mail, are included in this industry.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - steady

key_trends: The USPS has an exclusive right to manage postage, letters and mailbox deliveries. Internal competition is nonexistent since the postal service is the only major player.
The postal service faces external competition from private courier service providers regarding package delivery. Cellphones, e-mail and social media are sources of external competition.

Revenue has fallen slightly in the current period. Due to the popularity of rival industries, the postal service has been unable to gain any new ground in the period, shrinking its revenue and causing a loss of profit.

The USPS will endure a long-term drop in the outlook period. External competition from e-mail, online media and private courier service companies will fuel these drops. The postal service will seek to innovate and cut its operations to prevent more losses.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The USPS delivers most of its mail to households and individuals, who comprise more than nine-tenths of its revenue. Since most of the United States population lives in cities, delivery to residents in urban areas makes up more than half of their revenue. As rival carriers are plentiful in cities and suburbs, consumers in these areas have started to use them more than the USPS, so the share of revenue going to city residents has been receding during the current period.

The postal service is required by law to serve households in rural areas, so residents outside of cities and suburbs comprise nearly one-third of revenue. Courier services don't get as much business in rural areas, so the USPS still has a strong foothold in these parts of the country, with this causing the share of revenue to expand during the current period.

P.O. boxes are locations where mail for individuals and businesses is stored at a local post office. Many people still use them to preserve their privacy and Security Some view mailing directly to a personal or home address as very dangerous.

Highway contracts involve the USPS paying a third party to deliver mail from one point to another. These contracts enable the postal service to reduce costs. Even as these services remain essential, those who can opt to use the Internet to send messages have been reducing their revenue share during the period.

Businesses often order mail and packages using the USPS, as they comprise nearly one-tenth of revenue. But rival industries, like private mail carriers, also offer an identical type of service, cutting into this industry and causing its revenue share to drop during the period.

The Digital Economy Has Hurt Spending on Marketing Mail With these factors, postal carriers must consider the volume of mail they send out, reducing this segment's revenue share. Formerly called standard mail, USPS marketing mail includes advertisements and merchandise weighing fewer than 16 ounces. Marketing mail enables companies to distribute these advertisements to businesses and individuals without needing specific names or addresses. But with online advertisements nearly replacing traditional formats like print, the need for physical mail to distribute advertisements has been falling.

A Strong Economy Boosted Spending on Shipping and Packaging The USPS handles and ships merchandise and packages weighing up to 70 pounds. Part of this segment includes priority mail, which enables customers to receive their packages from the postal service within three days. USPS has a widespread distribution network and a large workforce of delivery workers. As the economy recovers, shipping and packaging have been going up again, causing this segment's revenue share to climb up.

Changing International Factors Have Shrunk More Spending on International Mail The USPS manages all inbound and outbound international mail within the boundaries of the United States. As geopolitical tensions have been scaling up between the US and specific countries, mailing activities to affected regions have temporarily or permanently shut down. Rival industries offering nearly identical services to what the Postal Service offers have been downplaying the need for this service, reducing its share in the period.

Periodicals Have Become Less Important Because of the Popularity of Online Media The USPS has been distributing periodicals to households for a long time. Periodicals include magazines, newspapers and other forms of publications. As more people get their information from the internet through social media and news websites, periodicals' revenue share has been falling. The availability of online periodicals has also been undercutting this segment as those who subscribe to newsletters or read content online give them access to content that was once exclusively tangible.

The USPS Also Provides a Host of Other Services Other mailing services include money orders, delivery confirmation, mail insurance, return receipts, envelopes, cards and other accessory services. As packaging becomes more popular, the need for extra services to help ease packaging deliveries has been rising, causing this segment's total revenue share to go up.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Postal carriers rely on a stream of market activity from upstream industries
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Postal carriers rely on a stream of market activity from upstream industries that will need their services to distribute their products. Print advertising expenditures measure how much spending will be necessary from this industry. As expenditures go up for print advertising, there will be a larger market for print-based formats like magazines and newspapers, two items that postal carriers distribute to subscribers.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic region, specifically the New York metropolitan area, contains many of the nation's major banks, private equity firms and financial institutions. Since these companies manage lots of significant information, they receive and send lots of documents through the mail, raising demand for the postal service in the Mid-Atlantic.

The Southeast region is home to big states such as Florida, Tennessee, Virginia and North Carolina, which makes the region populated. Since the area contains many people, there's a high penetration of businesses, individuals and organizations. These groups need mail and packages, so spending on postal services in the Southeast is very high, giving the USPS its highest share of establishments out of any region.

The Plains region is very rural and has a low population density, so it comprises a small share of the US population. Since the USPS must serve rural areas, many post offices are located in the Plains states since the infrastructure required to deliver mail and packages to remote parts of the country is significant.

The West region contains large cities such as Seattle, Los Angeles and San Francisco. Most of the population lives in these cities, so the population density is very high. Since most households and businesses are close to each other, the USPS needs fewer post offices to distribute mail and packages, so this region's share of establishments is much smaller than its proportion of the US population.

regulations_points.regulation_description: This law reorganized the Post Office from a Cabinet-level department to an independent executive agency. The United States Postal Service (USPS) entered into modern operations in 1971 under the leadership of the Postmaster General and a Board of Governors appointed by the President. The act also requires that employees receive just compensation and that the postal service offers services to all parts of the country.

The Postal Reorganization Act established the PRC. The organization must review and regulate all rate and fee changes and the USPS must report the costs, revenue and volume of international mail to the PRC and Congress.

regulations_points.regulation_title: POSTAL ACCOUNTABILITY AND ENHANCEMENT ACT OF 2006
regulations_points.regulation_description: This act divided USPS activities into two categories: "market-dominant" products and "competitive" products. Market-dominant products cover goods and services that the industry has a monopoly over, such as First-Class Mail. Competitive products include all other goods and services, such as delivery services. It also reorganized the Postal Rate Commission to the Postal Regulatory Commission, which sets rates for both product categories. Market-dominant rates are adjusted annually according to the consumer price index.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The postal service industry is in the decline stage of its life cycle.
The market share concentration in the postal service industry is high.

basis_points.basis_description: The USPS has an exclusive right to manage postage, letters and mailbox deliveries, so internal competition is nonexistent.
The USPS faces external competition from private courier services for package delivery, as well as from cellphones, email and social media.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The government mandates that the USPS is the only major player in the postal service industry, with no competitors allowed for mail delivery.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: LABOR IS ESSENTIAL FOR THE FUNCTIONING OF THIS INDUSTRY
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Postal service workers deliver mail to households and businesses throughout the country. Serving these demographics is the main function of this industry, so labor costs make up a significant chunk of revenue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: CUTS AND CHANGES TO THE POSTAL SERVICE ENABLE LOWER PURCHASES
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: These costs include transportation and basic supplies, such as postal vehicles, that carriers may need when performing their duties. Even as inflation remains a top concern, the USPS has been able to reduce its purchases during this period through its reform efforts, reducing its reliance on various types of ventures.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: THE POSTAL SERVICE OFTEN OPERATES AT A LOSS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The costs the USPS endures often exceed the revenue it gains, so the industry reports a loss. These losses do not impact the agency since taxpayers can bail out the Postal Service in case of financial struggle. Recently, the USPS has been losing profit because of inflationary pressures and dipping revenue despite efforts to cut their losses by reducing their costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Labor provides a much higher barrier to entry for courier service providers seeking to compete with the USPS in the package delivery industry. Sending packages throughout the United States requires meaningful investment in workers who drive vehicles and go door-to-door.

volatility_points.volatility_title: INCREASED COMPETITION FROM SUBSTITUTES IS A LONG-TERM ISSUE
volatility_points.volatility_description: The popularity of email, online media and private courier service providers has been cutting into revenue as they evolve in popularity and gain traction among more types of audiences. Revenue drops resulting from higher competition occur at a long-term and steady pace, so the postal service doesn't endure more revenue volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: SHIFTING PUBLIC ATTITUDES SHAPES ITS OPERATIONS, AFFECTING ITS PERFORMANCE
volatility_points.volatility_description: The structure of the USPS has also been hurting the industry as it lacks the power to hike up their prices without the approval of their regulatory bodies.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Mobile Apps Make First-Class Mail Delivery More Attractive
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The USPS has employed mobile apps to offer customers tracking systems for their packages. With these systems, individuals can track the schedule of their mail and receive notifications when it has been delivered. Employing these tracking systems helps consumers see how their packages are doing, easing the package delivery process and boosting consumer appeal and revenue growth.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: SAME-DAY DELIVERY KEEPS THE USPS IN THE GAME
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The Postal Service has been using new software to help it communicate better with its delivery centers and customers. Better communication between centers enables the USPS to deliver packages to consumers within one day. Same-day delivery enables the USPS to remain efficient, so it still competes successfully with other courier services.

FAQs.question: What strategies do you use to attract online businesses as clients for mail and package delivery?
FAQs.answer: Online businesses can be a significant source of postal service revenue with their high volume of package deliveries.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in serving residential or business consumers, or do you serve a range of downstream clients?
FAQs.answer: The US Postal Service is mandated by law to provide services across the country in every big and small region. Households comprise the large majority of revenue.

FAQs.question: Since the USPS relies on trucks, have volatile crude oil prices affected your operations?
FAQs.answer: The USPS uses vehicles to deliver mail parcels so gas is a key input for operations. When crude oil prices rise, purchase costs often decline for the USPS.

FAQs.question: Does the USPS have control over the location of its hubs, and can it strategically place them near high-demand regions?
FAQs.answer: The USPS has hubs across the United States based on the spread of the population and what makes logistic sense for the delivery of mail and parcels.

FAQs.question: How does your company leverage technologies, such as Multiline Optical Character Readers (MLOCR), to improve operational efficiencies?
FAQs.answer: MLOCR technologies enable the USPS to quick read addresses, apply barcodes on envelopes and sort more than nine envelopes per second. Wide area barcode readers can scan barcodes located virtually anywhere on a letter, and the Advanced Facer Canceller System positions mail and cancels stamps at a rate of 36,000 pieces per hour.

FAQs.question: How is your company investing in other new technologies to get a leg up on external competitors?
FAQs.answer: Technology investments for the USPS have remained very low because of a substantial lack of funding. Technology has lagged compared with private competitors such as FedEx and UPS.

FAQs.question: How have regulatory changes affected your business?
FAQs.answer: Saturday deliveries were nearly canceled to reduce operational costs for the USPS. These were still kept in practice.

FAQs.question: How did your company adapt to changing regulations pertaining to COVID-19?
FAQs.answer: - The USPS provided masks, gloves and cleaning products to all of its employees. - The company also arranged purchasing channels so employees could buy additional materials for work and personal use. - The USPS changed rules in its physical establishments, requesting all customers wear facemasks while updating cleaning frequency and policies and provided 80 hours of paid leave for non-career employees.

FAQs.question: How do you mitigate the financial impacts of decreased demand for traditional mail services?
FAQs.answer: As digital communications become increasingly popular, managing the impacts on traditional mail services is vital.

FAQs.question: How have internal costs, such as high retirement and healthcare contributions, affected the USPS's profit?
FAQs.answer: Large healthcare and retirement costs have led to large losses rather than operational costs such as fuel. For more than a decade, the USPS has struggled to mitigate the costs of its retirement and healthcare accounts to ensure gains, but to little avail.

FAQs.question: Are you able to successfully pass high operational costs along to your end consumer?
FAQs.answer: Under the Postal Accountability and Enhancement Act of 2006, postal rates are regulated by the Postal Regulatory Commission according to the consumer price index. USPS must successfully increase delivery rates to make up for lower mail volume, so the USPS has little control over passing along cost increases.

FAQs.question: What technological innovations has the USPS implemented to improve efficiencies? Have these assisted in lower or mitigating rising operational costs?
FAQs.answer: This industry is labor intensive. New technology can automate mail sorting, processing and tracking, which will reduce wage costs and improve the industry's performance.

FAQs.question: Do you outsource parts of your operation? How can you improve relationships with other parties?
FAQs.answer: USPS must develop alliances with other parties, especially to facilitate e-commerce. For example, it has developed a package delivery relationship with Amazon but has not disclosed many details.

FAQs.question: How has the spike in e-commerce sales during COVID-19 affected your business? Do you rely on e-commerce sales to generate revenue?
FAQs.answer: E-commerce sales measure the percentage of all manufactured goods and products sold by online e-businesses. The Postal Service often suffers when e-commerce sales rise, as many online retail platforms have agreements set up with other delivery services, such as UPS and FedEx.

FAQs.question: How does corporate profit affect your business?
FAQs.answer: This driver measures corporate profit earned across all industries. Profit is defined as earnings before interest and taxes.

FAQs.question: Do fluctuations in the consumer confidence index (CCI) often affect your business?
FAQs.answer: People conduct more transactions and mail correspondences when consumer confidence is high, which increases demand for postal services.
